title: Northern Nevada calls for public help in updating regional hazard mitigation plan
message:
Northern Nevada is at risk for 13 identified natural and man-made disasters, and local governments work hard to plan for those disasters and practice ways to mitigate the damage.
The Washoe region is currently reviewing and updating its Hazard Mitigation Plan and is seeking the public’s assistance to ensure that the perspectives, needs and ideas of all its residents are considered in the plan.
These actions can include building defensible space around one’s house to protect against wildfire, or having an evacuation plan in place, staying current on vaccines and healthcare to prevent infectious disease.
You can learn preparation and mitigation tools from the experts at a special open house May 18 at 10 a.m. at the Washoe County Administration Complex, 1001 E. 9th Street, Reno.
Local emergency managers will be available to talk about specific hazards that may be a threat to the region.
location: Washoe County Administration Complex, 1001 E. 9th Street, Reno
event_breakdown:
- Northern Nevada is at risk for 13 identified natural and man-made disasters
- Local governments are working hard to plan for those disasters and practice ways to mitigate the damage
- The Washoe region is currently reviewing and updating its Hazard Mitigation Plan

- Actions can include building defensible space around one’s house to protect against wildfire, having an evacuation plan in place, and staying current on vaccines and healthcare to prevent infectious disease
- A special open house will be held on May 18 at 10 a.m. at the Washoe County Administration Complex, 1001 E. 9th Street, Reno
- Experts will be available to provide preparation and mitigation tools
- Local emergency managers will be available to talk about specific hazards that may be a threat to the region

title: Hurricane Preparedness Week : take action when a storm threatens
message:
If a storm is expected to impact your area, put your hurricane plan in motion immediately to be ready ahead of the storm.
In addition to basic survival needs, don’t forget other supplies such as chargers, medicine, and hygiene products.
Plan to have enough for at least three days, and don’t forget about your pets.
While preparing these basic needs, don't forget to keep your phone charged, and make sure to fill up/charge your vehicle as well.
Help them prepare for a storm and help them evacuate if needed.
location: storm
event_breakdown:
1. Storm Preparedness:
   - Advise to put hurricane plan in motion ahead of expected storm.
   - Gather basic survival needs, including chargers, medicine, and hygiene products.
   - Plan for at least three days' worth of supplies, including provisions for pets.
   - Keep phone charged and ensure vehicle is fueled.
   - Assist others in storm preparation and evacuation if necessary.

title: Disease and hunger soar in Latin America after floods and drought , study finds
message:
Hunger and disease are rising in Latin America after a year of record heat, floods and drought, a report by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has shown.
Latin America and the Caribbean have experienced some of the worst effects.
Other areas of Central and South America endured unusually fierce heat and prolonged drought.
Combined with drought, this has hurt agricultural production in one of the world’s most important food production regions.
Overall, Latin America has suffered significant calorific losses, the report said.
location: Latin America
event_breakdown:
1. Hunger and disease rising in Latin America due to extreme weather events, according to World Meteorological Organization report.
   - Location: Latin America
2. Latin America and the Caribbean experiencing severe impacts from extreme weather.
   - Location: Latin America, Caribbean
3. Central and South America facing intense heat and prolonged drought.
   - Location: Central America, South America
4. Agricultural production in Latin America affected by drought, leading to significant calorific losses.
   - Location: Latin America

title: $2 . 7bn plan to protect Miami - Dade from storm surge headed to Congress
message:
A fast-tracked plan to start armoring parts of Miami-Dade County around Biscayne Bay against powerful hurricane storm surge will soon be headed to Congress for authorization.
It also includes millions of dollars to study the effectiveness of reefs, mangroves and other nature-based solutions on shredding storm surge, which will help determine future features.
The revised strategy came after an initial Corps plan that relied heavily on engineered armoring, including towering flood walls and gates, drew criticism in 2018.
“This is about how you can protect an urban community from storm surge.
I just wonder if there’s another way to be protecting the whole community using some of these nature-based solutions," she said.

title: Governor Signs Tax Relief Package | 96 . 3 | 102 . 5 NewsRadio WFLA
message:
Emphasizing a sales-tax “holiday” for hurricane preparedness supplies, Governor Ron DeSantis on Tuesday signed an annual package of tax breaks.
The package is expected overall to trim state and local revenue by 440 million dollars during the upcoming fiscal year.
Lawmakers included a series of sales-tax holidays in the package, including two periods when shoppers will be able to stock up on hurricane supplies without paying sales taxes.
The first preparedness holiday will start June 1st, at the start of the hurricane season, while the second will be from August 24th to September 6th, just before the peak of the storm season.
The package also includes a back-to-school tax holiday, and others on recreation-related purchases and tools and other work supplies.
location: Florida
event_breakdown:
- Governor Ron DeSantis signs annual package of tax breaks, including sales-tax "holiday" for hurricane preparedness supplies
- Package expected to trim state and local revenue by $440 million during upcoming fiscal year
- Inclusion of sales-tax holidays for hurricane supplies, back-to-school items, recreation-related purchases, and tools/work supplies
- First hurricane preparedness holiday to start on June 1st, coinciding with the start of hurricane season
- Second hurricane preparedness holiday scheduled from August 24th to September 6th, just before the peak of the storm season

title: Dozens of cholera cases reported in flood - hit Kenya
message:
Many parts of Kenya have been hit by floods that have destroyed homes and engulfed roads and bridges (LUIS TATO)The United Nations voiced concern on Wednesday after dozens of cases of cholera were reported in flood-stricken Kenya as the death toll from rain-related disasters surpassed 250.
The World Health Organization (WHO) said 44 cases of the disease have been reported in Tana River County in eastern Kenya, one of the areas hardest hit in weeks of destructive rains and flooding.
Cholera is an acute intestinal infection that spreads through contaminated food and water and typically causes severe diarrhoea, vomiting and muscle cramps.
- Death toll rises -The death toll since March has climbed to 257, according to Kenyan government spokesman Isaac Mwaura.

title: 2023  year of record climatic hazard in Latin America : UN
message:
JAM STA ROSA / AFPMONTEVIDEO, Uruguay (AFP)— Latin America and the Caribbean had their warmest year on record in 2023 as a “double-whammy” of El Nino and climate change caused major weather calamities, the World Meteorological Organization said Wednesday.
“Unfortunately, 2023 was a year of record climatic hazards in Latin America and the Caribbean, WMO Secretary-General Celeste Saulo said in a statement.
“El Nino conditions during the second half of 2023 contributed to a record warm year and exacerbated many extreme events.
Severe drought — exacerbated by heatwaves — affected large areas of Latin America, including much of Central America, forcing a reduction in shipping through the Panama Canal.
Further south, parts of Brazil, Peru, Bolivia, Paraguay and Argentina were stricken by wildfires amid record temperatures.

title: Storm assault on Chinese ports a wake - up call for climate risks
message:
As Typhoon Doksuri aimed toward mainland China, major southeast ports were forced to turn away dozens of vessels for days.
The storm — supercharged by the warm July waters of the Pacific — delivered Beijing's worst flooding in more than 50 years, shuttering factories, ruining crops, collapsing homes and displacing tens of thousands of people.
China's losses from natural disasters in July and August stood at an estimated $10 billion.
But that official Chinese damage tally reflected only a fraction of the costs wrought by the typhoon.
Rebuilding flood-hit areas and climate-proofing infrastructure will cost far more — with China issuing 1 trillion yuan ($139 billion) of sovereign bonds to help.

title: New $20M Coverage for California Commercial Property E & S Risks in Wildfire Prone Areas
message:
Wildfire Defense Insurance Services is offering a $20 million excess and surplus commercial property coverage for E&S risks in wildfire prone areas of California.
WDIS offers E&S commercial property insurance with WDSresponse, provided by WDIS’ affiliate partner, Wildfire Defense Systems, a wildfire services provider that specializes in the placement of commercial E&S wildfire risks through retail agents.
Last month, Munich Re Specialty Insurance announced it is offering a FAIR Plan Commercial Wrap, available to commercial insureds in California who seek comprehensive coverage in tandem with their coverage from the FAIR Plan, the state’s insurer of last resort.
Sold through wholesale brokers, the product gives businesses access to coverage for property damage – including water damage, burst pipe coverage and other non-fire perils – that the FAIR plan excludes.

title: Floods Displace Thousands in East Africa ; IOM Calls for Sustained Efforts to Address Climate Mobility
message:
Floods Displace Thousands in East Africa; IOM Calls for Sustained Efforts to Address Climate MobilityGeneva/ Nairobi, 8 May – Weeks of heavy rainfall and flooding in the East Africa region has triggered widespread displacement with hundreds of thousands displaced across Burundi, Kenya, Rwanda, Somalia, Ethiopia and Tanzania.
“The unprecedented and devastating flooding has unveiled the harsh realities of climate change, claiming lives and displacing communities.
Africa is highly vulnerable to climate change, despite contributing only about 4 per cent to global greenhouse gas emissions.
As the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) global climate change discussions in Germany draw near this June, set to shape the agenda for the Conference of Parties (COP), it becomes evident that discussions on climate change must now include considerations of human mobility.
Note to EditorsEast African leaders have signed and committed to the Kampala Ministerial Declaration on Migration, Environment and Climate Change, which addresses both the challenges and the opportunities of climate mobility.

title: Akiya houses : Super - aged Japan now has 9 million vacant homes . And that a problem
message:
Abandoned houses are known in Japan as “akiya” – a term that usually refers to derelict residential homes tucked away in rural areas.
“This is a symptom of Japan’s population decline,” said Jeffrey Hall, a lecturer at Kanda University of International Studies in Chiba.
“It’s not really a problem of building too many houses” but “a problem of not having enough people,” he said.
“When an earthquake or a tsunami occurs, there is a possibility that vacant houses will block evacuation routes as they break down and get destroyed,” he said.
In other rural areas with a high concentration of vacant houses, akiya have stalled development, the professor said.

title: Governor Abbott deploys additional resources ahead of West Texas fire threat
message:
AUSTIN, TEXAS – JANUARY 31: Texas Gov.
Greg Abbott listens to reporters during a news conference on January 31, 2023 in Austin, Texas.
Abbott held a meeting and news conference in preparation for the winter storm that is sweeping across portions of Texas.
On Tuesday, Governor Greg Abbott directed the Texas Division of Emergency Management (TDEM) to deploy additional state emergency response resources ahead of increased wildfire danger in the Panhandle and West Texas.
“Following the largest wildfire in our state’s history, Texas stands ready to provide all available resources to assist firefighters and local officials and protect Texas communities,” said Governor Abbott.

title: Unprecedented flooding displaces hundreds of thousands across east Africa
message:
Never-ending emergency“The (displacement) numbers keep rising,” the UN agency said, noting that the flooding emergency was one of the “harsh realities” of climate change, which has claimed lives and uprooted entire communities.
IOMBurundi“As these individuals face the daunting task of rebuilding, their vulnerability only deepens,” said Rana Jaber, IOM Regional Director for East and Horn of Africa.
Africa is highly vulnerable to climate change despite contributing only about four per cent to global greenhouse gas emissions.
The East and Horn of Africa has particularly been impacted by alternating cycles of drought and intense precipitation over the last decade, IOM maintained.
East African leaders have already signed and committed to the Kampala Ministerial Declaration on Migration, Environment and Climate Change to address the “challenges and the opportunities of climate mobility”, IOM said.

title: London plans future flood defence as Thames Barrier turns 40
message:
London, May 8 : Flood defence walls through London will need to be half a metre higher in the future to protect against climate change, officials said as they marked the 40th anniversary of the Thames Barrier.
These include raising the flood walls and defences that line the Thames downriver of the barrier by half a metre by 2040 and then by the same amount by 2050, to the west, through central London.
He said of the barrier: "It's like the sleeping giant, it rolls into action, it wakes up when that is needed."
Storms and weeks of heavy rain bringing high river flow down the Thames meant the barrier was closed 50 times in 13 weeks, including 20 closures on consecutive high tides.
If that intense use were to be replicated more frequently, it would not leave time for the maintenance the barrier needs to ensure it works when required.

title: London future flood defences plans as  sleeping giant  Thames Barrier turns 40
message:
The barrier, officially opened by Queen Elizabeth II, on May 8, 1984, and operated by the Environment Agency, was designed to protect London from flooding until 2030, but the “sleeping giant” is now expected to function until 2070.
But with sea levels expected to rise by a metre by 2100 along with increasingly intense storms driven by climate change, officials say greater defences against flooding will be needed in the coming decades.
These include raising the flood walls and defences that line the Thames downriver of the barrier by half a metre by 2040, and then by the same amount by 2050, to the west, through central London.
While the barrier has met the challenge it was designed for – including rising sea levels factored in before climate change was part of the conversation – the winter of 2013/2014 was extremely difficult.
If that intense use were to be replicated more frequently, it would not leave time for the maintenance the barrier needs to ensure it works when required.

Whitaker and Herb Simmons, director of the St. Clair County Emergency Management Agency, advised residents to sign up for CodeRED emergency alerts at www.alertstclair.com.
The potentially damaging storms expected Wednesday are the latest in a spate of severe weather this spring, including a storm April 18 during which eight “weak” tornadoes developed in southwestern Illinois.

Abandoned houses are known in Japan as “akiya” – a term that usually refers to derelict residential homes tucked away in rural areas.
“This is a symptom of Japan’s population decline,” said Jeffrey Hall, a lecturer at Kanda University of International Studies in Chiba.
According to figures compiled by the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications, 14% of all residential properties in Japan are vacant.
“When an earthquake or a tsunami occurs, there is a possibility that vacant houses will block evacuation routes as they break down and get destroyed,” he said.
In other rural areas with a high concentration of vacant houses, akiya have stalled development, the professor said.

title: U . S . weather : Forecasters warn Midwest after Okla . tornado
message:
OKLAHOMA CITY -Several Midwest states were bracing for dangerous storms Tuesday as tornadoes spun through parts of Michigan, one day after a powerful twister roared through a small Oklahoma town, killing at least one person and destroying dozens of homes.
Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee.
A deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa.
The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that "a large and life-threatening tornado" was headed toward Barnsdall.
The storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.

title: Midwest to brace for dangerous storms after deadly Oklahoma tornado
message:
Debris and damage from powerful storms that hit Barnsdall, Oklahoma.
Photo / APWeather forecasters warned residents in several Midwest states to brace for dangerous storms, a day after a powerful twister roared through a small Oklahoma town, killing at least one person and destroying dozens of homes.

title: East Africa Unprecedented Flooding Displaces Hundreds of Thousands
message:
More than 637,000 people have been affected by weeks of deluges including 234,000 displaced in just the last five days.
Never-ending emergency"The (displacement) numbers keep rising," the UN agency said, noting that the flooding emergency was one of the "harsh realities" of climate change, which has claimed lives and uprooted entire communities.
Africa is highly vulnerable to climate change despite contributing only about four per cent to global greenhouse gas emissions.
East African leaders have already signed and committed to the Kampala Ministerial Declaration on Migration, Environment and Climate Change to address the "challenges and the opportunities of climate mobility", IOM said.
But greater efforts are needed to support its implementation, "including advocating for the inclusion of climate mobility at global climate discussions such as the upcoming COP29 in November 2024, taking place in Baku, Azerbaijan".

title: After deadly Oklahoma tornado , storms bring twisters to the Midwest
message:
OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) — Severe storms battered parts of the Midwest on Tuesday, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes in the region one day after a deadly twister ripped through a small Oklahoma town and killed at least one person.
Forecasters warn that the storms could stretch late into the night as portions of the three states were under a tornado watch.
Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, and at least one tornado was spotted in Kansas, South Dakota, Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee.
The deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa.
First responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said.

title: African Union insurance agency to disburse $60M for drought relief
message:
The African Union’s climate insurance agency will disburse $60 million to Malawi, Zambia, Zimbabwe, and Mozambique to mitigate drought impacts driven by El Niño.
Sign up for your early morning brew of the BizNews Insider to keep you up to speed with the content that matters.
By Antony SguazzinThe African Union’s climate insurance agency will pay out at least $60 million to four southern African nations to help them offset the impact of a drought that’s been driven by the El Niño weather pattern, its director general said.
Malawi, Zambia, Zimbabwe and Mozambique will receive payments at the end of the harvesting season in a few weeks time, Ibrahima Cheikh Diong, who leads the African Risk Capacity agency, said in an interview in Johannesburg on Tuesday.
African Risk Capacity operates a parametric insurance model, which triggers drought compensation payments according to the impact of timing, amount and distribution of rainfall.

title: Storms battering the Midwest bring tornadoes , hail and strong winds
message:
PAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) — At least eight tornadoes have touched down in Ohio and three have been confirmed in Michigan as severe storms barreled through the central U.S. late Tuesday and early Wednesday, killing one man in Tennessee when a tree toppled onto his vehicle.
Tornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, according to the National Weather Service.
The National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties.
The weather service said crews are still surveying areas of Franklin and Butler counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well.
In Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties — all in the southwestern part of the state.
location: Kalamazoo

message:

title: Preparing for more storms across eastern Kentucky
message:
BOYD COUNTY, Ky. (WSAZ) - It’s the calm before the storm with emergency management crews on standby, as another round of storms are expected to pick up later Wednesday evening.
“Be prepared before you go to bed and have multiple ways to receive those warnings,” said Tim England, Boyd County Emergency Management Director.
England says a helpful tip is making sure you have everything you need before you go to bed when it comes to night-time storms.
For example, having a flashlight on hand, plus your phone and portable charger handy.
England says the potential for flooding from streams and creeks is at the forefront.

title: A few storms tomorrow , better chance Friday
message:
TALLAHASSEE, Fla. (WCTV) - Strong storms are the main focus late tomorrow for some, and a better opportunity for more of the area on Friday.
This could bring a few rounds of strong to possibly severe storms to the area early Friday morning and another round for some in the afternoon.

title: Poor planning begets disaster - The Standard
message:
El Niño-induced droughtTHE front page lead story in our NewsDay edition yesterday made very interesting and revealing reading.
Ncube said government “didn’t know how deep the drought was” and so it was pleasantly “surprised” that the drought was “much deeper” than it thought.
The drought will surely have devastating effects on our already battered economy which is in desperate need of respite.
We are in this mess all because of poor planning.
And a typical example of this poor planning is that we don’t have any grain reserves to speak of, yet we used to have them and could even afford to feed others in times of drought.

title: Deadly storms claim 100 lives , damage 100 , 000 homes in south Brazil - World News
message:
At least 100 people have died and nearly 100,000 homes have been destroyed or significantly damaged from more than a week of record rainfall and flooding in south Brazil's Rio Grande do Sul state, local authorities said on Wednesday.
The National Confederation of Municipalities said in an update that overflowing rivers and floods in the state have affected around 1.45 million people and forced some 200,000 residents to flee their homes.
As many as 414 of 497 towns in the state, a top agricultural and livestock producer that borders Argentina and Uruguay, have suffered from the storms and declared emergencies.
The confederation estimates the economic losses at 4.6 billion reals (about 904 million US dollars), taking into account the damage to housing and public infrastructure, as well as agriculture, livestock, industry, commerce and services.
In just one week, Rio Grande do Sul saw five months' worth of rain, sparking unprecedented flooding.

title: Waco three - day watering limits to take effect in July
message:
Waco water users starting in July will only be allowed to use sprinklers three days per week under an updated drought contingency plan the Waco City Council approved Tuesday.
Along with the updated drought contingency plan, the council approved a new long-term water conservation plan, almost two months after the plans were introduced to the council.
In addition to the new drought plan, city staff also showcased a water conservation plan prepared by engineering consulting firm CDM Smith designed to preserve Waco’s water resources for the next century.
WateringThe biggest change to Waco’s drought plan is a permanent three-day-per-week watering schedule.
Drought stagesUnder the new plan, the triggers for drought stage levels have been altered and will kick in sooner compared to the old plan.

title: Marion County residents learn how to spot severe storms , thanks to NWS meteorologist
message:
OCALA, Fla. (WCJB) - With less than a month before hurricane season, meteorologists at the National Weather Service in Jacksonville stopped in Marion County, teaching residents how severe storms develop.
The SKYWARN Spotter Class was held at the Marion County Sheriff’s Office Emergency Operations Center Wednesday night.
Meteorologist Kip Bricker led the presentation, teaching residents the difference between severe weather watches and warnings, how thunderstorms develop, and how to monitor severe storms, amongst other topics.
Another session is scheduled at the Alachua County Emergency Operations Center on May 28.

title: What is the Main Development Region ( MDR ) of the North Atlantic Ocean ?
message:
The Main Development Region of the Atlantic Ocean runs from Africa to the Caribbean Islands and is an area where the majority of tropical cyclones form.
The area is annually home to some of the warmest water, allowing tropical cyclones to develop quickly during the heart of the hurricane season.
Climatologists estimate that 85% of major hurricanes and 60% of all other tropical cyclones form in either the Caribbean or the Atlantic MDR.
During the modern satellite era, tropical cyclone seasons in 1968, 1977, 1982, 1991, 1993 and 2003 produced minimal or no activity in the MDR.
Original article source: What is the Main Development Region (MDR) of the North Atlantic Ocean?
location: The Caribbean Islands
event_breakdown:
1. The Main Development Region (MDR) of the Atlantic Ocean stretches from Africa to the Caribbean Islands, serving as a prime area for tropical cyclone formation.
2. Annually, the MDR hosts some of the warmest water, facilitating rapid development of tropical cyclones, especially during peak hurricane season.
3. Climatologists estimate that 85% of major hurricanes and 60% of other tropical cyclones originate in either the Caribbean or the Atlantic MDR.
4. Minimal or no tropical cyclone activity occurred in the MDR during specific seasons in the modern satellite era: 1968, 1977, 1982, 1991, 1993, and 2003.

title: Tornadoes tear through southeastern US as storms leave 3 dead – Metro US
message:
Amid Wednesday’s storms, the National Weather Service continued issuing tornado warnings that stretch past midnight in North Carolina, Alabama, Georgia, Missouri and Kentucky.
A second person was killed in the city of Columbia in Maury County, where the National Weather Service said a likely tornado had touched down.
“Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order,” the National Weather Service warned when it issued a flash flood emergency.
The National Weather Service said tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana on Tuesday.
In Michigan, tornadoes swirled through the southwestern part of the state, in and around Kalamazoo County, according to the National Weather Service.
location: 当前地区当日额度已消耗完, 请尝试更换网络环境
event_breakdown:
1. National Weather Service issues tornado warnings stretching past midnight in North Carolina, Alabama, Georgia, Missouri, and Kentucky.
2. Second person killed in Columbia, Maury County, due to likely tornado touchdown.
3. National Weather Service issues flash flood emergency warning, advising against travel unless fleeing flooding or under evacuation order.
4. Tornadoes touch down in parts of Michigan, Ohio, and Indiana, as reported by the National Weather Service.
5. Tornadoes swirl through southwestern Michigan, particularly in and around Kalamazoo County, according to the National Weather Service.

title: El Niño Disasters in Panama and Latin America
message:
The El Niño phenomenon and the effects of global warming due to human activity caused a record of climate disasters in Latin America and the Caribbean in 2023.
Among the climate disasters of 2023, the WMO highlighted Hurricane Otis, which devastated the Mexican resort of Acapulco in October, leaving at least 45 dead and millions in damage.
The drought in the Plata basin affected northern Argentina and southern Brazil and especially hit Uruguay, which experienced its driest summer in 42 years and experienced a critical lack of water.
The WMO also warned that the rise in sea level is accelerating.
The rate of rise in mean sea level in the South Atlantic and the subtropical and tropical North Atlantic exceeds the global average.
location: 当前地区当日额度已消耗完, 请尝试更换网络环境
event_breakdown:
1. Record of climate disasters in Latin America and the Caribbean in 2023 attributed to the El Niño phenomenon and human-induced global warming.
2. Hurricane Otis highlighted as a significant climate disaster, causing devastation in Acapulco, Mexico, resulting in casualties and extensive damage.
3. Drought in the Plata basin affects northern Argentina, southern Brazil, and Uruguay, leading to critical water shortages, particularly in Uruguay, experiencing its driest summer in 42 years.
4. Warning from the WMO regarding the acceleration of sea-level rise, with rates exceeding the global average in the South Atlantic and subtropical/tropical North Atlantic regions.

title: Powerful storms kill three as tornadoes tear through parts of US
message:
The National Weather Service had previously reported a likely tornado on the ground in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles (72 kilometres) south of Nashville.
The National Weather Service said water rescues were ongoing in those areas and described the flooding from heavy thunderstorms as life-threatening.
The National Weather Service in Nashville on Wednesday evening issued a tornado watch for parts of Arkansas, Mississippi, Missouri and Tennessee until 3am central daylight time.
The weather service said crews are still surveying areas in other counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well.
In southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early on Wednesday.

title: Powerful storms kill three as tornadoes tear through parts of US
message:
The National Weather Service had previously reported a likely tornado on the ground in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles (72 kilometres) south of Nashville.
The National Weather Service said water rescues were ongoing in those areas and described the flooding from heavy thunderstorms as life-threatening.
The National Weather Service in Nashville on Wednesday evening issued a tornado watch for parts of Arkansas, Mississippi, Missouri and Tennessee until 3am central daylight time.
The weather service said crews are still surveying areas in other counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well.
In southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early on Wednesday.
